elements.content: A porous two-dimensional (2D) metal–organic framework (MOF), namely, [Cd­(PBA)­(DMF)]·DMF (Cd-PBA), has been solvothermally synthesized by the reaction of 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid ligand (H2PBA) and Cd­(II) ions. Structural analysis shows that Cd-PBA possesses 2D (3,6)-connected kgd net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83) and exhibits two distinct types of one-dimensional opening channels along a- and c-axes. The incorporation of Cd metal centers and −NH groups of amides endows Cd-PBA rich open metal sites and Lewis basic sites, which are applied as an efficient catalyst for the important Knoevenagel condensation and cyanosilylation of aldehyde reactions. This Cd-PBA presents highly efficient catalytic activity and recyclability for both Knoevenagel condensation reaction and cyanosilylation of various aldehydes with trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN). The excellent catalytic activity can be maintained at least four cycles without loss of obvious catalytic activity. These results indicate Cd-PBA can serve as a promising heterogeneous catalyst toward C–C bond formation due to the stability and high catalytic activity.
elements.clean_text: A porous two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic framework (MOF), namely, [Cd(PBA)(DMF)]⋅DMF (Cd-PBA), has been solvothermally synthesized by the reaction of 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid ligand (H2PBA) and Cd(II) ions. Structural analysis shows that Cd-PBA possesses 2D (3,6)-connected kgd net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83) and exhibits two distinct types of one-dimensional opening channels along a- and c-axes. The incorporation of Cd metal centers and -NH groups of amides endows Cd-PBA rich open metal sites and Lewis basic sites, which are applied as an efficient catalyst for the important Knoevenagel condensation and cyanosilylation of aldehyde reactions. This Cd-PBA presents highly efficient catalytic activity and recyclability for both Knoevenagel condensation reaction and cyanosilylation of various aldehydes with trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN). The excellent catalytic activity can be maintained at least four cycles without loss of obvious catalytic activity. These results indicate Cd-PBA can serve as a promising heterogeneous catalyst toward C-C bond formation due to the stability and high catalytic activity.

elements.content: A two-dimensional porous Cd-based metal−organic framework (Cd-PBA) with kgd topology is presented. This multifunctional material shows open metal sites and Lewis basic sites for heterogeneous catalysis, which could promote the cyanosilylation reaction and Knoevenagel condensation reaction. The high catalytic activity and stability made Cd-PBA a promising catalyst toward C−C bond formation.
elements.clean_text: A two-dimensional porous Cd-based metal-organic framework (Cd-PBA) with kgd topology is presented. This multifunctional material shows open metal sites and Lewis basic sites for heterogeneous catalysis, which could promote the cyanosilylation reaction and Knoevenagel condensation reaction. The high catalytic activity and stability made Cd-PBA a promising catalyst toward C-C bond formation.

elements.content: Nowadays, porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as the particular field of materials science, is being extensively studied due to their intriguing topologies and the multifunctional properties, such as separation and gas storage, catalysis science, magnetism, luminescence, etc. Particularly interesting are those related to the application of heterogeneous catalysis. It is feasible and fundamental to predict the possible catalytic properties and activity through reasonable design and fine characterization of these materials. For instance, the selection of ligand and metal center can direct the structural diversity with variable topological structures and accessibility to the active center. Generally speaking, one effective strategy is to create coordinated unsaturated metal sites or to introduce nanosized metallic clusters/organometallic complexes into the MOFs through a postmodification method. Another effective strategy is to fabricate functionalized ligands to synthesize desired MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as the particular field of materials science, is being extensively studied due to their intriguing topologies and the multifunctional properties, such as separation and gas storage, catalysis science, magnetism, luminescence, etc. Particularly interesting are those related to the application of heterogeneous catalysis. It is feasible and fundamental to predict the possible catalytic properties and activity through reasonable design and fine characterization of these materials. For instance, the selection of ligand and metal center can direct the structural diversity with variable topological structures and accessibility to the active center. Generally speaking, one effective strategy is to create coordinated unsaturated metal sites or to introduce nanosized metallic clusters/organometallic complexes into the MOFs through a postmodification method. Another effective strategy is to fabricate functionalized ligands to synthesize desired MOFs.

elements.content: We have been studying the design of functionalized MOFs and their application for heterogeneous catalysis. As reported in our previous work, we obtained a polyhedral metal–organic framework, [Eu2(PDC)3] (H2PDC = pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid), which could effectively accelerate the cyanosilylation reaction. By utilizing a versatile CuII/CuI metal–organic framework as catalyst, three-component coupling reactions of diisopropylamine, tosylazide, and aromatic alkynes can be promoted as well as the oxidation of benzylic compounds. As part of our continuous work, herein, we reported the synthesis and characterization of a 2D (3,6)-connected framework with kgd topology, namely, [Cd­(PBA)­(DMF)]·DMF (H2PBA = 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid). Moreover, the catalytic properties were also studied.
elements.clean_text: We have been studying the design of functionalized MOFs and their application for heterogeneous catalysis. As reported in our previous work, we obtained a polyhedral metal-organic framework, [Eu2(PDC)3] (H2PDC = pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid), which could effectively accelerate the cyanosilylation reaction. By utilizing a versatile CuII/CuI metal-organic framework as catalyst, three-component coupling reactions of diisopropylamine, tosylazide, and aromatic alkynes can be promoted as well as the oxidation of benzylic compounds. As part of our continuous work, herein, we reported the synthesis and characterization of a 2D (3,6)-connected framework with kgd topology, namely, [Cd(PBA)(DMF)]⋅DMF (H2PBA = 5-(4-pyridin-3-yl-benzoylamino)-isophthalic acid). Moreover, the catalytic properties were also studied.

elements.content: The organic ligand was synthesized based on the procedures described previously. All reagents and solvents employed were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were collected from KBr pellets on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer. PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to carry out the elemental analyses. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F3 Tarsus from room temperature to 900 °C under flowing nitrogen. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were characterized on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu target tube. A Varian 500 MHz spectrometer was used to record 1H NMR spectra. Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-MP gas sorption analyzer was applied to measure sorption isotherms. The size and shape were characterized by using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, TESCAN Maia 3, Czech) operating at 5 kV and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100HR, Japan) coupled with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information

The organic ligand was synthesized based on the procedures described previously. All reagents and solvents employed were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were collected from KBr pellets on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer. PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to carry out the elemental analyses. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F3 Tarsus from room temperature to 900 °C under flowing nitrogen. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were characterized on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu target tube. A Varian 500 MHz spectrometer was used to record 1H NMR spectra. Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-MP gas sorption analyzer was applied to measure sorption isotherms. The size and shape were characterized by using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, TESCAN Maia 3, Czech) operating at 5 kV and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100HR, Japan) coupled with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV.

elements.content: A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), and dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 90 °C for 3 d and then cooled to room temperature. Block crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3366 (s), 1646 (vs), 1558 (w), 1425 (w), 1394 (w), 1307 (w), 782 (w), 717 (w). Anal. Calcd for C26H26N4O7Cd (618.91) C 50.46, H 4.23, N 9.05%; found C 50.42, H 4.27, N 9.03%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Cd(PBA)(DMF)]⋅DMF

A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), and dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 90 °C for 3 d and then cooled to room temperature. Block crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3366 (s), 1646 (vs), 1558 (w), 1425 (w), 1394 (w), 1307 (w), 782 (w), 717 (w). Anal. Calcd for C26H26N4O7Cd (618.91) C 50.46, H 4.23, N 9.05%; found C 50.42, H 4.27, N 9.03%.

elements.content: X-ray reflection intensities were performed with a Bruker APEX II diffractometer at 296 K using graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The empirical absorption corrections were used to correct the reflections. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL programs (SHELXTL-2014). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters at the final cycles. An isotropic displacement parameter was used to place the organic hydrogen atoms in calculated positions. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement are summarized in Table S1, and the selected bond lengths are listed in Table S2. CCDC 1580065 contains the crystallographic data.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

X-ray reflection intensities were performed with a Bruker APEX II diffractometer at 296 K using graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The empirical absorption corrections were used to correct the reflections. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL programs (SHELXTL-2014). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters at the final cycles. An isotropic displacement parameter was used to place the organic hydrogen atoms in calculated positions. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement are summarized in Table S1, and the selected bond lengths are listed in Table S2. CCDC 1580065 contains the crystallographic data.

elements.content: Prior to the catalytic test, the as-prepared Cd-PBA samples were soaked in CH3OH for 3 days. Further, the samples were filtrated and dried at 120 °C for 5 h under vacuum to remove the physical and chemical guest molecules, generating the dehydrated phase Cd-PBA.
elements.clean_text:
Sample Activation

Prior to the catalytic test, the as-prepared Cd-PBA samples were soaked in CH3OH for 3 days. Further, the samples were filtrated and dried at 120 °C for 5 h under vacuum to remove the physical and chemical guest molecules, generating the dehydrated phase Cd-PBA.

elements.content: In a 10 mL Pyrex-glass screw-cap vial were placed successively benzaldehyde (100 μL, 1 mmol), malononitrile (111 μL, 2 mmol), ethanol (5 mL), and activated Cd-PBA (9.5 mg, 0.02 mmol, 2%). Then, the mixture was stirred with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 2 h. After that, the supernatant was filtered and concentrated under reduced pressure. The reaction crudes were further purified by flash column chromatography, and the yields of the reaction products were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy by using dibromomethane as an internal standard.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure for Knoevenagel Condensation Reaction

In a 10 mL Pyrex-glass screw-cap vial were placed successively benzaldehyde (100 μL, 1 mmol), malononitrile (111 μL, 2 mmol), ethanol (5 mL), and activated Cd-PBA (9.5 mg, 0.02 mmol, 2%). Then, the mixture was stirred with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 2 h. After that, the supernatant was filtered and concentrated under reduced pressure. The reaction crudes were further purified by flash column chromatography, and the yields of the reaction products were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy by using dibromomethane as an internal standard.

elements.content: A mixture of benzaldehyde (26.5 mg, 0.25 mmol), trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN, 49.6 mg, 0.5 mmol), and n-hexane (5 mL) was placed into a Pyrex-glass screw-cap vial (10 mL), and Cd-PBA catalyst (2%) was added. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 8 h. The yields were determined by 1H NMR analysis using dibromomethane as an internal standard.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure for Cyanosilylation Reaction

A mixture of benzaldehyde (26.5 mg, 0.25 mmol), trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN, 49.6 mg, 0.5 mmol), and n-hexane (5 mL) was placed into a Pyrex-glass screw-cap vial (10 mL), and Cd-PBA catalyst (2%) was added. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 8 h. The yields were determined by 1H NMR analysis using dibromomethane as an internal standard.

elements.content: Structural analysis reveals that Cd-PBA crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. As depicted in a, the Cd ion is six-coordinated and exhibits an octahedral coordination surrounded by one N atom, four carboxylate oxygen atoms of three different PBA2– ligands, and one oxygen atom from a coordinated DMF molecule. The neighboring Cd­(II) ions are connected together through the carboxylate groups of PBA2– ligands to form a 1D infinite chain (b) in which the carboxylate groups adopt the bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging coordination modes. These chains are further linked by PBA2– ligands using the N atoms to give rise to a 2D layer network (c). A better insight into the nature of this structure can be achieved by the application of a topology approach; each PBA2– ligand acts as organic trinodal building block and the binuclear cadmium atoms serve as hexatopic node geometry (Figure S1). Thus, the whole framework can be ascribed as a binodal (3,6)-connected kagomé dual (kgd) net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83) analyzed by the Topos 4.0 program (d). Although the adjacent layers are packed in an ABCABC arrangement (Figure S2), the stacking still leads to two different types of one-dimensional (1D) opening channels with effective size of 8.9 × 8.0 Å2 and 9.3 × 7.8 Å2 along a- and c-axis, respectively (e,f), in which the void space is filled with DMF molecules. PLATON calculation suggests a solvent accessible volume of 507.1 Å3 (39.6% of unit cell) by excluding the guest solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure and Characterization of Cd-PBA MOF

Structural analysis reveals that Cd-PBA crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. As depicted in a, the Cd ion is six-coordinated and exhibits an octahedral coordination surrounded by one N atom, four carboxylate oxygen atoms of three different PBA2- ligands, and one oxygen atom from a coordinated DMF molecule. The neighboring Cd(II) ions are connected together through the carboxylate groups of PBA2- ligands to form a 1D infinite chain (b) in which the carboxylate groups adopt the bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging coordination modes. These chains are further linked by PBA2- ligands using the N atoms to give rise to a 2D layer network (c). A better insight into the nature of this structure can be achieved by the application of a topology approach; each PBA2- ligand acts as organic trinodal building block and the binuclear cadmium atoms serve as hexatopic node geometry (Figure S1). Thus, the whole framework can be ascribed as a binodal (3,6)-connected kagomé dual (kgd) net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83) analyzed by the Topos 4.0 program (d). Although the adjacent layers are packed in an ABCABC arrangement (Figure S2), the stacking still leads to two different types of one-dimensional (1D) opening channels with effective size of 8.9 × 8.0 Å2 and 9.3 × 7.8 Å2 along a- and c-axis, respectively (e,f), in which the void space is filled with DMF molecules. PLATON calculation suggests a solvent accessible volume of 507.1 Å3 (39.6% of unit cell) by excluding the guest solvent molecules.

elements.content: Crystal structure of Cd-PBA. (a) Coordination environment of Cd­(II). (b) 1D chain connected through the carboxylate groups in Cd-PBA. (c) Polyhedral view of 2D network. (d) View of the (3,6)-connected kgd net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83). A space-filling view of the porous network showing two different types of 1D channels along the crystallographic (e) a-axis, and (f) c-axis, in which the solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of Cd-PBA. (a) Coordination environment of Cd(II). (b) 1D chain connected through the carboxylate groups in Cd-PBA. (c) Polyhedral view of 2D network. (d) View of the (3,6)-connected kgd net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83). A space-filling view of the porous network showing two different types of 1D channels along the crystallographic (e) a-axis, and (f) c-axis, in which the solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were first applied to observe the morphology of the as-prepared Cd-PBA samples. As presented in Figure S3, the average size of the MOF particle is approximately 3 μm. To confirm the phase purity of Cd-PBA, PXRD pattern for the bulk samples was measured at room temperature. Figure S4 shows that all the diffraction peaks perfectly match well with the simulated pattern results, confirming the phase purity of the obtained crystal samples. The intensity differences may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline samples.
elements.clean_text: Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were first applied to observe the morphology of the as-prepared Cd-PBA samples. As presented in Figure S3, the average size of the MOF particle is approximately 3 μm. To confirm the phase purity of Cd-PBA, PXRD pattern for the bulk samples was measured at room temperature. Figure S4 shows that all the diffraction peaks perfectly match well with the simulated pattern results, confirming the phase purity of the obtained crystal samples. The intensity differences may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline samples.

elements.content: Meanwhile, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for crystal samples was also performed under nitrogen atmosphere. As shown in Figure S5, the TG curve in the range of 100–150 °C shows a first loss of 12.52%, corresponding to the loss of one solvent DMF molecule (calcd. 12.61%). The second weight loss of 11.71% ranges from 150 to 400 °C due to the loss of one coordinated DMF molecule (calcd 11.81%). Above 500 °C, an abrupt weight loss appears, which is ascribed to the decomposition of the framework. The final residual after thermal decomposition was presumed to be CdO (found 21.1%, calcd 20.7%).
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for crystal samples was also performed under nitrogen atmosphere. As shown in Figure S5, the TG curve in the range of 100-150 °C shows a first loss of 12.52%, corresponding to the loss of one solvent DMF molecule (calcd. 12.61%). The second weight loss of 11.71% ranges from 150 to 400 °C due to the loss of one coordinated DMF molecule (calcd 11.81%). Above 500 °C, an abrupt weight loss appears, which is ascribed to the decomposition of the framework. The final residual after thermal decomposition was presumed to be CdO (found 21.1%, calcd 20.7%).

elements.content: Nitrogen sorption experiments were carried out to evaluate the pore characteristics. To activate the sample, the fresh samples were immersed in CH3OH solvent for 3 days, then heated under vacuum at 120 °C for 5 h to remove all the solvent molecules, generating the dehydrated phase Cd-PBA. No obvious weight loss of the dehydrated phase was observed at the starting temperature (Figure S6), suggesting the complete removal of all the uncoordinated and coordinated solvent molecules. Moreover, PXRD pattern further confirmed that the framework remained intact and the preservation of its crystallinity (Figure S4). Based on the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms in Figure S7, the porous Cd-PBA exhibited a typical type-I curve with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 768 m2 g–1 and a total pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g–1. The pore-size distribution calculated by Barrett–Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method reveals the pore diameter is about 8.5 Å, which is in agreement with the crystal structure analysis (Figure S8). This porous and robust framework property could provide a platform to carry out a heterogeneous catalytic reaction.
elements.clean_text: Nitrogen sorption experiments were carried out to evaluate the pore characteristics. To activate the sample, the fresh samples were immersed in CH3OH solvent for 3 days, then heated under vacuum at 120 °C for 5 h to remove all the solvent molecules, generating the dehydrated phase Cd-PBA. No obvious weight loss of the dehydrated phase was observed at the starting temperature (Figure S6), suggesting the complete removal of all the uncoordinated and coordinated solvent molecules. Moreover, PXRD pattern further confirmed that the framework remained intact and the preservation of its crystallinity (Figure S4). Based on the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms in Figure S7, the porous Cd-PBA exhibited a typical type-I curve with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 768 m2 g-1 and a total pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g-1. The pore-size distribution calculated by Barrett-Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) method reveals the pore diameter is about 8.5 Å, which is in agreement with the crystal structure analysis (Figure S8). This porous and robust framework property could provide a platform to carry out a heterogeneous catalytic reaction.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that there exits the −NH groups of amides in the framework, suggesting that desolvated Cd-PBA might serve as an active catalyst for Lewis base-promoted reactions. Therefore, the Lewis base-catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation reactions of carbonyl compounds with malononitrile in the presence of Cd-PBA as catalyst were carried out. As we know, the Knoevenagel reaction is a weakly basic condensation reaction, as an important member of the C–C bond formation reaction family, which is employed in the synthesis of fine chemicals and pharmaceutical products. Because Cd-PBA is insoluble in most organic solvents, we used ethanol, cyclohexane, n-hexane, acetonitrile, benzene, dichloromethane, tetrahydrofuran, and DMF as solvents. As shown in , the reaction yields in ethanol and benzene solvents were more accelerated in comparison with other organic solvents. However, due to the toxicity of the benzene solvent, we used ethanol as a catalytic solvent instead in this case.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Performances

It is interesting to note that there exits the -NH groups of amides in the framework, suggesting that desolvated Cd-PBA might serve as an active catalyst for Lewis base-promoted reactions. Therefore, the Lewis base-catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation reactions of carbonyl compounds with malononitrile in the presence of Cd-PBA as catalyst were carried out. As we know, the Knoevenagel reaction is a weakly basic condensation reaction, as an important member of the C-C bond formation reaction family, which is employed in the synthesis of fine chemicals and pharmaceutical products. Because Cd-PBA is insoluble in most organic solvents, we used ethanol, cyclohexane, n-hexane, acetonitrile, benzene, dichloromethane, tetrahydrofuran, and DMF as solvents. As shown in , the reaction yields in ethanol and benzene solvents were more accelerated in comparison with other organic solvents. However, due to the toxicity of the benzene solvent, we used ethanol as a catalytic solvent instead in this case.

elements.content:
Reaction of Benzaldehyde with Malononitrile in the Presence of Cd-PBA: Effect of Solvents entry solvent time (h) yield (%) isolated yield (%) 1 ethanol 2 91 86 2 cyclohexane 6 51 40 3 n-hexane 6 57 42 4 acetonitrile 4 72 65 5 benzene 2 92 85 6 dichloromethane 8 6 7 tetrahydrofuran 6 75 58 8 DMF 10 8

Reaction conditions: catalyst (0.02 mmol), benzaldehyde (1 mmol), malononitrile (2 mmol), solvent (5 mL). Yield determined by 1H NMR analysis using CH2Br2 as an internal standard.

Isolated yield after column chromatography.

Herein, we employed a molar ratio of 1:2 to select aromatic benzaldehyde and malononitrile compounds in ethanol at room temperature for 2 h with 2% catalyst loading, which generated the corresponding product yield of 91% for 2 h (, entry 1). The yield is slightly less than the powerful Lewis base catalyst [Cd3(tipp)­(bpdc)2] with a 93% conversion after 1 h with 0.6% catalyst loading. However, the experimental condition was conducted at the temperature of 60 °C. Meanwhile, our catalyst presents a significant improvement compared to the other reported MOF catalysts. For comparison, a series of control experiments were conducted. Obviously, when the reaction was carried out in the absence of catalyst, only 6% conversion of target products were achieved, demonstrating the excellent catalytic performance of Cd-PBA for the formation of a C–C bond. Additionally, to verify the active sites, we used Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O as a homogeneous catalyst instead of Cd-PBA; however, a negligible conversion of 3% was observed. By utilizing the H2PBA ligand as a catalyst, we can catalyze the reaction with a yield of 39% under the similar condition. Furthermore, when Cd­(NO3)·4H2O was used as a catalyst, H2PBA ligand was utilized as an additive, and a moderate yield of 31% was observed. These results indicate that −NH groups of amides have influence on promoting the catalytic reaction. When the unactivated Cd-PBA samples were used instead of the activated ones, the catalytic results are inferior to that of dehydrated Cd-PBA under similar conditions (yield: 54%), which indicates that the catalytic active sites might be easily blocked by the solvent molecule and that the substrates have to compete with the solvent molecules during the catalytic process.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we employed a molar ratio of 1:2 to select aromatic benzaldehyde and malononitrile compounds in ethanol at room temperature for 2 h with 2% catalyst loading, which generated the corresponding product yield of 91% for 2 h (, entry 1). The yield is slightly less than the powerful Lewis base catalyst [Cd3(tipp)(bpdc)2] with a 93% conversion after 1 h with 0.6% catalyst loading. However, the experimental condition was conducted at the temperature of 60 °C. Meanwhile, our catalyst presents a significant improvement compared to the other reported MOF catalysts. For comparison, a series of control experiments were conducted. Obviously, when the reaction was carried out in the absence of catalyst, only 6% conversion of target products were achieved, demonstrating the excellent catalytic performance of Cd-PBA for the formation of a C-C bond. Additionally, to verify the active sites, we used Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O as a homogeneous catalyst instead of Cd-PBA; however, a negligible conversion of 3% was observed. By utilizing the H2PBA ligand as a catalyst, we can catalyze the reaction with a yield of 39% under the similar condition. Furthermore, when Cd(NO3)⋅4H2O was used as a catalyst, H2PBA ligand was utilized as an additive, and a moderate yield of 31% was observed. These results indicate that -NH groups of amides have influence on promoting the catalytic reaction. When the unactivated Cd-PBA samples were used instead of the activated ones, the catalytic results are inferior to that of dehydrated Cd-PBA under similar conditions (yield: 54%), which indicates that the catalytic active sites might be easily blocked by the solvent molecule and that the substrates have to compete with the solvent molecules during the catalytic process.

elements.content: To expand the scope of Cd-PBA catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation reaction, various substrates were treated under similar conditions. On one hand, substrates with different size and shape have an apparent effect on the product yields (, entries 1–3). As evident from , substrates of increasing dimensions are also tested. As for ethyl cyanoacetate (3.4 × 7.3 Å2), the product yield was 37% in 2 h (, entry 2). In the case of the even larger tert-butyl cyanoacetate (4.3 × 8.2 Å2), the reaction almost did not proceed (, entry 3). With the size of the benzaldehyde derivatives further increasing, for example, 1-naphthaldehyde (5.9 × 7.2 Å2), the yield decreased obviously to 42% under the same conditions (, entry 4). Similar size-selective behaviors can also be observed in the previously reported MOF-based heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, we performed the FT-IR experiments of Cd-PBA cayalyst before and after catalytic reactions (). By simply immersing the as-prepared Cd-PBA samples in benzaldehyde solution for 2 h, some small peaks between 2820 and 2742 cm–1 appeared in the IR spectrum of the solid sample, confirming the presence of aldehyde (−CHO) in the porous framework. However, the IR spectrum of Cd-PBA after catalytic reaction displayed a small peak at 2216 cm–1, which resulted from the CN vibration characteristics, implying the presence of cyano-group in the Cd-PBA catalyst. In order to get insight into the influence of different substituents in the aromatic aldehydes, a variety of benzaldehyde derivatives with active methylene compounds were selected as substrates. The electronic groups on the aromatic aldehydes have a significant effect on the reaction outcome (entries 5–9). Aldehydes with electron-withdrawing groups provide higher yield than those with electron-donating ones. As shown in , benzaldehyde derivatives bearing electron-withdrawing groups, such as 4-nitrobenzaldehyde, 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde, and 4-bromobenzaldehyde, are fully converted to the catalytic products with the highest conversion of 100% after 2 h (entries 7–9). Nevertheless, malononitrile reacted with electron-donating groups, such as 4-methylbenzaldehyde and 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, to give relatively low product yields (entries 5–6). The tendency could be explained by the faster activation and higher electropositive charge on the carbonyl group due to nucleophilic attack, resulting in excellent conversions in the catalytic reactions. In contrast, the activation of the carbonyl group is lower in the presence of electron-donating groups, leading to a lower yield in the nucleophilic reactions.
elements.clean_text: To expand the scope of Cd-PBA catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation reaction, various substrates were treated under similar conditions. On one hand, substrates with different size and shape have an apparent effect on the product yields (, entries 1-3). As evident from , substrates of increasing dimensions are also tested. As for ethyl cyanoacetate (3.4 × 7.3 Å2), the product yield was 37% in 2 h (, entry 2). In the case of the even larger tert-butyl cyanoacetate (4.3 × 8.2 Å2), the reaction almost did not proceed (, entry 3). With the size of the benzaldehyde derivatives further increasing, for example, 1-naphthaldehyde (5.9 × 7.2 Å2), the yield decreased obviously to 42% under the same conditions (, entry 4). Similar size-selective behaviors can also be observed in the previously reported MOF-based heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, we performed the FT-IR experiments of Cd-PBA cayalyst before and after catalytic reactions (). By simply immersing the as-prepared Cd-PBA samples in benzaldehyde solution for 2 h, some small peaks between 2820 and 2742 cm-1 appeared in the IR spectrum of the solid sample, confirming the presence of aldehyde (-CHO) in the porous framework. However, the IR spectrum of Cd-PBA after catalytic reaction displayed a small peak at 2216 cm-1, which resulted from the CN vibration characteristics, implying the presence of cyano-group in the Cd-PBA catalyst. In order to get insight into the influence of different substituents in the aromatic aldehydes, a variety of benzaldehyde derivatives with active methylene compounds were selected as substrates. The electronic groups on the aromatic aldehydes have a significant effect on the reaction outcome (entries 5-9). Aldehydes with electron-withdrawing groups provide higher yield than those with electron-donating ones. As shown in , benzaldehyde derivatives bearing electron-withdrawing groups, such as 4-nitrobenzaldehyde, 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde, and 4-bromobenzaldehyde, are fully converted to the catalytic products with the highest conversion of 100% after 2 h (entries 7-9). Nevertheless, malononitrile reacted with electron-donating groups, such as 4-methylbenzaldehyde and 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, to give relatively low product yields (entries 5-6). The tendency could be explained by the faster activation and higher electropositive charge on the carbonyl group due to nucleophilic attack, resulting in excellent conversions in the catalytic reactions. In contrast, the activation of the carbonyl group is lower in the presence of electron-donating groups, leading to a lower yield in the nucleophilic reactions.

It was noticed that the conversion was almost unchanged in the following 60 min, demonstrating the heterogeneity of the reaction.

elements.content: Considering the rich open metal sites in the whole framework, the acid-catalyzed cyanosilylation of aromatic aldehydes was also carried out as the model reaction. As is well-known, cyanosilylation reaction can be applied to obtain cyanohydrins for both organic synthesis and biological processes. Moreover, previous reports have shown that porous MOFs with coordinated unsaturated sites could promote the catalytic efficiencies for the cyanosilylation reaction, leading to the formation of a C–C bond. Herein, benzaldehyde (1 mmol) and trimethylsilylcyanide (TMSCN, 2 mmol) were reacted in n-hexane solvent with a catalyst loading of 2% Cd-PBA at room temperature. As presented in , Cd-PBA catalyst provides a 100% yield after 8 h, showing enhanced catalytic efficiency compared with those of the previously reported MOFs. For example, Tm­(BDC)1.5 reported by Sun afforded a moderate conversion of 57.4% of benzaldehyde after 5 h. The catalyst loading of 11 mol % Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3(BTT)8]2 gave a 98% yield after 9 h. Cu3(BTC)2, also known as HKUST-1, offered a 57% conversion at 313 K. However, our catalyst presents slightly less catalytic efficiency compared with Nd­(btc) catalyst, which showed 99% yield with a catalyst loading of 9.0% after 2 h. Given the high catalytic activity of Cd-PBA, we further evaluate the scope of substrates. As for 1-naphthaldehyde, the product yield of 58% was obtained after 8 h (, entry 2). In the case of larger 4-phenylbenzaldehyde, the yield reduced to 18% under the same conditions (, entry 3). Moreover, acetophenone was also used as a substrate; however, a negligible conversion of 12% was achieved under similar conditions due to its innate reduced reactivity (, entry 9). Similarly, aldehydes with electron-withdrawing groups are more reactive than those with electron-donating ones. As shown in , benzaldehyde derivatives bearing electron-donating groups (−CH3, −OCH3) give relatively low product yields (entries 4–5). Nevertheless, malononitrile reacted with electron-withdrawing benzaldehyde derivatives (−NO2, −OH, and −Br) is completely converted to the corresponding products with the highest yield after 2 h (entries 6–8). For comparison, we also used the unactivated MOF as the heterogeneous catalyst. However, a moderate yield of 35% was detected under similar catalytic conditions. The relative catalytic activity ratio of unactivated MOF vs activated MOF is 0.35, suggesting that the substrates have to compete with the solvent molecules in the framework and have less chances to access the metal centers.
elements.clean_text: Considering the rich open metal sites in the whole framework, the acid-catalyzed cyanosilylation of aromatic aldehydes was also carried out as the model reaction. As is well-known, cyanosilylation reaction can be applied to obtain cyanohydrins for both organic synthesis and biological processes. Moreover, previous reports have shown that porous MOFs with coordinated unsaturated sites could promote the catalytic efficiencies for the cyanosilylation reaction, leading to the formation of a C-C bond. Herein, benzaldehyde (1 mmol) and trimethylsilylcyanide (TMSCN, 2 mmol) were reacted in n-hexane solvent with a catalyst loading of 2% Cd-PBA at room temperature. As presented in , Cd-PBA catalyst provides a 100% yield after 8 h, showing enhanced catalytic efficiency compared with those of the previously reported MOFs. For example, Tm(BDC)1.5 reported by Sun afforded a moderate conversion of 57.4% of benzaldehyde after 5 h. The catalyst loading of 11 mol % Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3(BTT)8]2 gave a 98% yield after 9 h. Cu3(BTC)2, also known as HKUST-1, offered a 57% conversion at 313 K. However, our catalyst presents slightly less catalytic efficiency compared with Nd(btc) catalyst, which showed 99% yield with a catalyst loading of 9.0% after 2 h. Given the high catalytic activity of Cd-PBA, we further evaluate the scope of substrates. As for 1-naphthaldehyde, the product yield of 58% was obtained after 8 h (, entry 2). In the case of larger 4-phenylbenzaldehyde, the yield reduced to 18% under the same conditions (, entry 3). Moreover, acetophenone was also used as a substrate; however, a negligible conversion of 12% was achieved under similar conditions due to its innate reduced reactivity (, entry 9). Similarly, aldehydes with electron-withdrawing groups are more reactive than those with electron-donating ones. As shown in , benzaldehyde derivatives bearing electron-donating groups (-CH3, -OCH3) give relatively low product yields (entries 4-5). Nevertheless, malononitrile reacted with electron-withdrawing benzaldehyde derivatives (-NO2, -OH, and -Br) is completely converted to the corresponding products with the highest yield after 2 h (entries 6-8). For comparison, we also used the unactivated MOF as the heterogeneous catalyst. However, a moderate yield of 35% was detected under similar catalytic conditions. The relative catalytic activity ratio of unactivated MOF vs activated MOF is 0.35, suggesting that the substrates have to compete with the solvent molecules in the framework and have less chances to access the metal centers.

elements.content:
Cyanosilylation of Aromatic Aldehydes in the Presence of Cd-PBA<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn1"></xref>

Catalyst (2%), benzaldehyde (1 mmol), TMSCN (2 mmol), 5 mL of n-hexane, room temperature, 8 h.

Yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy with CH2Br2 as an internal standard.

Isolated yield after column chromatography.

Catalyzed by the unactivated Cd-PBA.

Catalyzed by a mixture of Cd­(NO3)3·6H2O and H2PBA ligands.

Moreover, we also carried out the control experiments for both catalytic cyanosilylation and Knoevenagel condensation reactions by using H2PBA and Cd­(NO3)·4H2O as catalysts instead of Cd-PBA, respectively, including those substrates with different sizes and electronic properties. In the case of Knoevenagel condensation reactions, moderate yield of the corresponding products could be obtained (), such as 31% for benzaldehyde, 15% for 4-methylbenzaldehyde, 19% for 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, 41% for 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde, 40% for 4-bromobenzaldehyde, and 37% for 4-nitrobenzaldehyde. These results show that the catalytic centers mainly result from the −NH groups of amides. However, as for the cyanosilylation reactions, all the results show inferior product yields, and the negligible yield below 10% can be detected for all the substrates (). These observations reveal the catalytic sites are ascribed to the coordinated unsaturated metal centers. The Cd2+ ion in Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O is in an eight-coordinated environment with four H2O molecules at the equatorial positions and four oxygen atoms from two nitrate ions at the apical positions. As a result, the Cd center of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O is blocked by the coordinated water molecules, making it more difficult to access the substrates.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, we also carried out the control experiments for both catalytic cyanosilylation and Knoevenagel condensation reactions by using H2PBA and Cd(NO3)⋅4H2O as catalysts instead of Cd-PBA, respectively, including those substrates with different sizes and electronic properties. In the case of Knoevenagel condensation reactions, moderate yield of the corresponding products could be obtained (), such as 31% for benzaldehyde, 15% for 4-methylbenzaldehyde, 19% for 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, 41% for 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde, 40% for 4-bromobenzaldehyde, and 37% for 4-nitrobenzaldehyde. These results show that the catalytic centers mainly result from the -NH groups of amides. However, as for the cyanosilylation reactions, all the results show inferior product yields, and the negligible yield below 10% can be detected for all the substrates (). These observations reveal the catalytic sites are ascribed to the coordinated unsaturated metal centers. The Cd2+ ion in Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O is in an eight-coordinated environment with four H2O molecules at the equatorial positions and four oxygen atoms from two nitrate ions at the apical positions. As a result, the Cd center of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O is blocked by the coordinated water molecules, making it more difficult to access the substrates.

elements.content: In summary, we presented a stable 2D Cd­(II)-based metal–organic framework with kgd net topology. Such a MOF features a bifunctional property with the combination of Lewis basic sites and open metal sites as efficient heterogeneous catalysis for the C–C bond formation, such as Knoevenagel condensation reaction and cyanosilylation of aromatic aldehydes. In both of the basic-catalyzed and acidic-catalyzed reactions, Cd-PBA exhibits higher catalytic activities to electron-withdrawing benzaldehyde derivatives compared with those of electron-donating groups during the catalytic process. More importantly, this MOF can be reused several times without the loss of obvious catalytic efficiency. The excellent catalytic activity and good stability prove Cd-PBA to be an efficient catalyst for the formation of a C–C bond.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we presented a stable 2D Cd(II)-based metal-organic framework with kgd net topology. Such a MOF features a bifunctional property with the combination of Lewis basic sites and open metal sites as efficient heterogeneous catalysis for the C-C bond formation, such as Knoevenagel condensation reaction and cyanosilylation of aromatic aldehydes. In both of the basic-catalyzed and acidic-catalyzed reactions, Cd-PBA exhibits higher catalytic activities to electron-withdrawing benzaldehyde derivatives compared with those of electron-donating groups during the catalytic process. More importantly, this MOF can be reused several times without the loss of obvious catalytic efficiency. The excellent catalytic activity and good stability prove Cd-PBA to be an efficient catalyst for the formation of a C-C bond.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), and dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 90 °C for 3 d and then cooled to room temperature. Block crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3366 (s), 1646 (vs), 1558 (w), 1425 (w), 1394 (w), 1307 (w), 782 (w), 717 (w). Anal. Calcd for C26H26N4O7Cd (618.91) C 50.46, H 4.23, N 9.05%; found C 50.42, H 4.27, N 9.03%.

Typical Procedure for Cyanosilylation Reaction

A mixture of benzaldehyde (26.5 mg, 0.25 mmol), trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN, 49.6 mg, 0.5 mmol), and n-hexane (5 mL) was placed into a Pyrex-glass screw-cap vial (10 mL), and Cd-PBA catalyst (2%) was added. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 8 h. The yields were determined by 1H NMR analysis using dibromomethane as an internal standard.

Herein, we employed a molar ratio of 1:2 to select aromatic benzaldehyde and malononitrile compounds in ethanol at room temperature for 2 h with 2% catalyst loading, which generated the corresponding product yield of 91% for 2 h (, entry 1). The yield is slightly less than the powerful Lewis base catalyst [Cd3(tipp)­(bpdc)2] with a 93% conversion after 1 h with 0.6% catalyst loading. However, the experimental condition was conducted at the temperature of 60 °C. Meanwhile, our catalyst presents a significant improvement compared to the other reported MOF catalysts. For comparison, a series of control experiments were conducted. Obviously, when the reaction was carried out in the absence of catalyst, only 6% conversion of target products were achieved, demonstrating the excellent catalytic performance of Cd-PBA for the formation of a C–C bond. Additionally, to verify the active sites, we used Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O as a homogeneous catalyst instead of Cd-PBA; however, a negligible conversion of 3% was observed. By utilizing the H2PBA ligand as a catalyst, we can catalyze the reaction with a yield of 39% under the similar condition. Furthermore, when Cd­(NO3)·4H2O was used as a catalyst, H2PBA ligand was utilized as an additive, and a moderate yield of 31% was observed. These results indicate that −NH groups of amides have influence on promoting the catalytic reaction. When the unactivated Cd-PBA samples were used instead of the activated ones, the catalytic results are inferior to that of dehydrated Cd-PBA under similar conditions (yield: 54%), which indicates that the catalytic active sites might be easily blocked by the solvent molecule and that the substrates have to compete with the solvent molecules during the catalytic process.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Cd(PBA)(DMF)]⋅DMF

A mixture containing H2PBA (72.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), and dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL) was sealed in a glass reaction bottle. The system was heated at 90 °C for 3 d and then cooled to room temperature. Block crystals were obtained by filtration and washed with DMF. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3366 (s), 1646 (vs), 1558 (w), 1425 (w), 1394 (w), 1307 (w), 782 (w), 717 (w). Anal. Calcd for C26H26N4O7Cd (618.91) C 50.46, H 4.23, N 9.05%; found C 50.42, H 4.27, N 9.03%.

Typical Procedure for Cyanosilylation Reaction

A mixture of benzaldehyde (26.5 mg, 0.25 mmol), trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN, 49.6 mg, 0.5 mmol), and n-hexane (5 mL) was placed into a Pyrex-glass screw-cap vial (10 mL), and Cd-PBA catalyst (2%) was added. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 8 h. The yields were determined by 1H NMR analysis using dibromomethane as an internal standard.

Herein, we employed a molar ratio of 1:2 to select aromatic benzaldehyde and malononitrile compounds in ethanol at room temperature for 2 h with 2% catalyst loading, which generated the corresponding product yield of 91% for 2 h (, entry 1). The yield is slightly less than the powerful Lewis base catalyst [Cd3(tipp)(bpdc)2] with a 93% conversion after 1 h with 0.6% catalyst loading. However, the experimental condition was conducted at the temperature of 60 °C. Meanwhile, our catalyst presents a significant improvement compared to the other reported MOF catalysts. For comparison, a series of control experiments were conducted. Obviously, when the reaction was carried out in the absence of catalyst, only 6% conversion of target products were achieved, demonstrating the excellent catalytic performance of Cd-PBA for the formation of a C-C bond. Additionally, to verify the active sites, we used Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O as a homogeneous catalyst instead of Cd-PBA; however, a negligible conversion of 3% was observed. By utilizing the H2PBA ligand as a catalyst, we can catalyze the reaction with a yield of 39% under the similar condition. Furthermore, when Cd(NO3)⋅4H2O was used as a catalyst, H2PBA ligand was utilized as an additive, and a moderate yield of 31% was observed. These results indicate that -NH groups of amides have influence on promoting the catalytic reaction. When the unactivated Cd-PBA samples were used instead of the activated ones, the catalytic results are inferior to that of dehydrated Cd-PBA under similar conditions (yield: 54%), which indicates that the catalytic active sites might be easily blocked by the solvent molecule and that the substrates have to compete with the solvent molecules during the catalytic process.

cln_elements.content:
Meanwhile, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for crystal samples was also performed under nitrogen atmosphere. As shown in Figure S5, the TG curve in the range of 100–150 °C shows a first loss of 12.52%, corresponding to the loss of one solvent DMF molecule (calcd. 12.61%). The second weight loss of 11.71% ranges from 150 to 400 °C due to the loss of one coordinated DMF molecule (calcd 11.81%). Above 500 °C, an abrupt weight loss appears, which is ascribed to the decomposition of the framework. The final residual after thermal decomposition was presumed to be CdO (found 21.1%, calcd 20.7%).

Nitrogen sorption experiments were carried out to evaluate the pore characteristics. To activate the sample, the fresh samples were immersed in CH3OH solvent for 3 days, then heated under vacuum at 120 °C for 5 h to remove all the solvent molecules, generating the dehydrated phase Cd-PBA. No obvious weight loss of the dehydrated phase was observed at the starting temperature (Figure S6), suggesting the complete removal of all the uncoordinated and coordinated solvent molecules. Moreover, PXRD pattern further confirmed that the framework remained intact and the preservation of its crystallinity (Figure S4). Based on the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms in Figure S7, the porous Cd-PBA exhibited a typical type-I curve with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 768 m2 g–1 and a total pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g–1. The pore-size distribution calculated by Barrett–Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method reveals the pore diameter is about 8.5 Å, which is in agreement with the crystal structure analysis (Figure S8). This porous and robust framework property could provide a platform to carry out a heterogeneous catalytic reaction.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Meanwhile, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for crystal samples was also performed under nitrogen atmosphere. As shown in Figure S5, the TG curve in the range of 100-150 °C shows a first loss of 12.52%, corresponding to the loss of one solvent DMF molecule (calcd. 12.61%). The second weight loss of 11.71% ranges from 150 to 400 °C due to the loss of one coordinated DMF molecule (calcd 11.81%). Above 500 °C, an abrupt weight loss appears, which is ascribed to the decomposition of the framework. The final residual after thermal decomposition was presumed to be CdO (found 21.1%, calcd 20.7%).

Nitrogen sorption experiments were carried out to evaluate the pore characteristics. To activate the sample, the fresh samples were immersed in CH3OH solvent for 3 days, then heated under vacuum at 120 °C for 5 h to remove all the solvent molecules, generating the dehydrated phase Cd-PBA. No obvious weight loss of the dehydrated phase was observed at the starting temperature (Figure S6), suggesting the complete removal of all the uncoordinated and coordinated solvent molecules. Moreover, PXRD pattern further confirmed that the framework remained intact and the preservation of its crystallinity (Figure S4). Based on the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms in Figure S7, the porous Cd-PBA exhibited a typical type-I curve with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 768 m2 g-1 and a total pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g-1. The pore-size distribution calculated by Barrett-Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) method reveals the pore diameter is about 8.5 Å, which is in agreement with the crystal structure analysis (Figure S8). This porous and robust framework property could provide a platform to carry out a heterogeneous catalytic reaction.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of Cd-PBA. (a) Coordination environment of Cd­(II). (b) 1D chain connected through the carboxylate groups in Cd-PBA. (c) Polyhedral view of 2D network. (d) View of the (3,6)-connected kgd net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83). A space-filling view of the porous network showing two different types of 1D channels along the crystallographic (e) a-axis, and (f) c-axis, in which the solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of Cd-PBA. (a) Coordination environment of Cd(II). (b) 1D chain connected through the carboxylate groups in Cd-PBA. (c) Polyhedral view of 2D network. (d) View of the (3,6)-connected kgd net topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83). A space-filling view of the porous network showing two different types of 1D channels along the crystallographic (e) a-axis, and (f) c-axis, in which the solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
